title: Users under the same project/root can launch other's VM when same cluster name is used
body:
SkyPilot cannot distinguish the clusters from different user accounts under the same GCP project / AWS root account / Azure subscription. That can cause a problem when the users accidentally specify the same cluster name as the other users.

From user requests.

title: Improve error handling for AWS region fetching
body:
<!-- Describe the changes in this PR -->

Some users face the following exception when updating the AWS catalog using the `fetch_aws` module:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File ".../sky/describe_regions.py", line 6, in <module>
    user_cloud_regions = aws_client.describe_regions()
  File ".../python3.10/site-packages/botocore/client.py", line 530, in _api_call
    return self._make_api_call(operation_name, kwargs)
  File ".../lib/python3.10/site-packages/botocore/client.py", line 960, in _make_api_call
    raise error_class(parsed_response, operation_name)
botocore.exceptions.ClientError: An error occurred (UnauthorizedOperation) when calling the DescribeRegions operation: You are not authorized to perform this operation.
```

This occurs when the [relevant permission](https://iam.cloudonaut.io/reference/ec2/DescribeRegions.html) is not enabled for their AWS account for the `DescribeRegions` call. This PR adds a helpful hint so that it's clear how to fix this issue.

With this PR:
```
RuntimeError: Failed to retrieve AWS regions. Please ensure that the `ec2:DescribeRegions` action is enabled for your AWS account.
```

<!-- Describe the tests ran -->
<!-- Unit tests (tests/test_*.py) are part of GitHub CI; below are tests that launch on the cloud. -->

Tested (run the relevant ones):

- [x] Tested using AWS account without the `DescribeRegions` permission

- [ ] Backward compatibility tests: `bash tests/backward_comaptibility_tests.sh`

title: GCP Ports Prototype
body:
<!-- Describe the changes in this PR -->

Allows you to open ports by using the `ports` feature in the YAML.

Works by creating a network tag for each cluster that matches the cluster name then an ingress firewall rule for that tag to allow connections from any source for the specified set of ports.

title: Make network check more reliable (1.1.1.1 could've been occupied)
body:
User reported that after #1800, their `status -r` failed due to their network setup occupying 1.1.1.1 (Cloudflare) for some reason. They could ping 8.8.8.8 (in the US).

```
urllib3.exceptions.MaxRetryError: HTTPSConnectionPool(host='1.1.1.1', port=443): Max retries exceeded with url: / (Caused by SSLError(SSLCertVerificationError(1, '[SSL: CERTIFICATE_VERIFY_FAILED] certificate verify failed: unable to get local issuer certificate (_ssl.c:1091)')))
```

Our choices:
- Get rid of this network check from the critical path of `status -r`
- If the above is not feasible, perhaps do both IP checks w/ fallback.

title: [AWS SSO] New UserId with every sky call
body:
After I've logged into AWS with SSO, I can see a UserId  in the format `AXXXXXXXXXXXXXX:botocore-session-<TIMESTAMP>` when I get the identity with `aws sts get-caller-identity`

However, sky commands seem to create a new AWS session with every call. This leads to errors like `'sky-abcd' (AWS) is owned by account 'AXXXXXXXXXXXXXX:botocore-session-TIMESTAMP1', but the activated account is 'AXXXXXXXXXXXXXX:botocore-session-TIMESTAMP2'`.

Any idea on how to resolve this?

title: Make rsync more resilient
body:
<!-- Describe the changes in this PR -->

Closes #1538.
- `rsync` related errors are normally related to transient network issues, so this adds "to fix" information for the user in error messages
- This also adds retrying to the `rsync` command to reduce the frequency of failures due to transient network issues

title: Improve ssh key name handling for Lambda
body:
<!-- Describe the changes in this PR -->
This pr fixes #1836 and #1837 by improving how we handle the ssh key name. We no longer use the ssh key name in `lambda_keys` and query Lambda Cloud instead (they have a new API for this). We also improve some error handling code when there is no ip address.

Tested:

- [x] `pytest tests/test_smoke.py --lambda` 
- [x] `sky launch --cloud lambda --num-nodes 2` on a gcp cluster
- [x] `sky launch --cloud lambda` after deleting `ssh key name` from `lambda_keys`

title: [Lambda] Handle deletion of ssh key from lambda_keys file
body:
When you remove the ssh key name from the `lambda_keys` file and `sky launch`, you get
```
  File "python3.9/site-packages/sky/backends/backend_utils.py", line 947, in _add_auth_to_cluster_config
    config = auth.setup_lambda_authentication(config)
  File "python3.9/site-packages/sky/authentication.py", line 326, in setup_lambda_authentication
    lambda_client.set_ssh_key(name, public_key)
  File "python3.9/site-packages/sky/skylet/providers/lambda_cloud/lambda_utils.py", line 174, in set_ssh_key
    raise_lambda_error(response)
  File "python3.9/site-packages/sky/skylet/providers/lambda_cloud/lambda_utils.py", line 84, in raise_lambda_error
    raise LambdaCloudError(f'{code}: {message}')
sky.skylet.providers.lambda_cloud.lambda_utils.LambdaCloudError: global/invalid-parameters: Key name must be unique
```
This situation likely occurs when someone deletes their `lambda_keys` file and creates a new one. We should handle this.

title: [Lambda] Launching Lambda cluster from SkyPilot cluster fails
body:
How to reproduce:
```
sky launch --cloud gcp
ssh # node
sky launch --cloud lambda
``` 
This is because `~./lambda_cloud` contains the local ssh key, not the one for the gcp node.

title: [Storage] Add validation checks for Store Name
body:
If the user specifies an invalid `name`, the error is thrown quite deep into the stack after we've sent the bucket request to boto3/gcs. We should catch it early and show it cleanly to the user.

This PR adds name validation for S3, R2 and GCSStores. 

Example:
```
file_mounts:
  /mydata/:
    name: s3://romil-bucket
    store: s3
```

Before:
```
<Long stack trace>

botocore.exceptions.ParamValidationError: Parameter validation failed:
Invalid bucket name "s3://romil-bucket": Bucket name must match the regex "^[a-zA-Z0-9.\-_]{1,255}$" or be an ARN matching the regex "^arn:(aws).*:(s3|s3-object-lambda):[a-z\-0-9]*:[0-9]{12}:accesspoint[/:][a-zA-Z0-9\-.]{1,63}$|^arn:(aws).*:s3-outposts:[a-z\-0-9]+:[0-9]{12}:outpost[/:][a-zA-Z0-9\-]{1,63}[/:]accesspoint[/:][a-zA-Z0-9\-]{1,63}$"
```

After:
```
Task from YAML spec: storage_test.yaml
sky.exceptions.StorageNameError: Prefix detected: `name` cannot start with s3://. If you are trying to use an existing bucket created outside of SkyPilot, please specify it using the `source` field (e.g. `source: s3://mybucket/`). If you are trying to create a new bucket, please use the `store` field to specify the store type (e.g. `store: s3`).
```

TODO:
- [x] Add test cases.

Tested:
- [x] Example YAML
- [x] Add more tests to `test_storage::TestStorageSpecValidation`
- [x] `test_smoke::TestStorageWithCredentials`

title: Missing GCP regions in catalog
body:
Currently the GCP catalog contains instances in the following regions:
```
List of supported gcp regions: 'asia-east1, europe-west4, us-central1, us-central2, us-east1, us-east4, us-east5, us-south1, us-west1, us-west2, us-west3, us-west4'
```
Is there a reason why many regions in Europe and Asia are missing (for instance `europe-west1`, `europe-west2`...)? The [Gcloud documentation](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/regions-zones) lists all available regions and many of them are missing. I am working with a Google Bucket located in Europe and would like to provision machines in the same zones to limit egress costs.

title: Region preference: try certain regions first before the lowest-cost ordering
body:
User requested:

> Is there a way to overwrite the region preference used by Sky? Specifically, I want to prefer us-east-1 over other regions, even if the spot price might be higher. The reason is that our s3 buckets are in us-east-1. When launching distributed training jobs in other regions, we not only pay more data transfer fees, but training iteration speed is also ~30% slower (reason not yet clear). 

The last part means that it's not enough for our optimizer to simply consider data egress costs and use that to hopefully select us-east-1. The user also observed lower training speed. This means the user would like the preference to really override our optimizer's choice.

> basically if there’s sufficient spot availability in us-east-1, prioritize this region; otherwise fallback to other regions.

title: [SSO/Spot] Fix spot controller failed to launch spot cluster when using SSO
body:
<!-- Describe the changes in this PR -->

A user reported that when using AWS SSO account, the `sky spot launch` will fail due to the controller does not have any cloud access enabled. That is a bug with our current SSO implementation, as the controller is assigned with an assumed IAM-role, which has the access to create the spot cluster and will not have static credential files, but our cloud access checking will fail when it finds there is no credential files.
Another problem with the spot controller is: the controller will keep retrying even if the all cloud disabled exception is raised, causing the spot job in STARTING status forever.

To reproduce:
1. Run in a new docker container
2. log in with SSO account
3. `sky spot launch -n test echo hi --retry-until-up`

This PR fixes:
1. The spot controller will now be able to launch the spot cluster when the user is using AWS SSO
2. Spot controller will be able to catch the all cloud disabled exception and fail early. (This is for any potential future identity problem with that exception)

title: [Provisioner] Support multi level performance disk
body:
<!-- Describe the changes in this PR -->

This PR introduces multi-level performance disks in all clouds. By specifying `disk_tier` in `sky.Resources` to one of `high`, `medium`, and `low`, a user could use a disk with custom performance. All clouds' current decisions and prices (256 GB for example) are shown below.

`disk_tier=low`
|Cloud|Disk Type|Benchmarked Read Throughput|Benchmarked Read IOPS|Benchmarked Write Throughput|Benchmarked Write IOPS|Price (GiB/mo)|Price (IOPS/mo)|Total Price Each Month|
|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|
|GCP|pd-standard|13.87 MB/s|211.63|37.17 MB/s|567.13|0.048|-|12.288|
|Azure|Standard_LRS|861.92 MB/s|13151.92|36.67 MB/s|559.54|-|-|11.328|
|AWS|standard|20.33 MB/s|310.14|282.19 MB/s|4305.91|0.066|-|16.896|

`disk_tier=medium`
|Cloud|Disk Type|Benchmarked Read Throughput|Benchmarked Read IOPS|Benchmarked Write Throughput|Benchmarked Write IOPS|Price (GiB/mo)|Price (IOPS/mo)|Total Price Each Month|
|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|
|GCP|pd-balanced|222.86 MB/s|3400.58|222.25 MB/s|3391.25|0.12|-|30.72|
|Azure|Premium_LRS|211.80 MB/s|3231.88|176.12 MB/s|2687.44|-|-|36.29|
|AWS|gp3 with IOPS=3500|241.43 MB/s|3683.87|199.15 MB/s|3038.86|0.09|0.005|25.54|

`disk_tier=high`
|Cloud|Disk Type|Benchmarked Read Throughput|Benchmarked Read IOPS|Benchmarked Write Throughput|Benchmarked Write IOPS|Price (GiB/mo)|Price (IOPS/mo)|Total Price Each Month|
|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|
|GCP|pd-ssd|342.91 MB/s|5232.42|268.17 MB/s|4091.91|0.203|-|51.968|
|Azure|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|
|AWS|gp3 with IOPS=7000|323.54 MB/s|4936.80|254.82 MB/s|3888.22|0.09|0.005|43.04|

Azure `disk_tier=high` is disabled now since a high-performance disk in Azure cannot be launched as an OS disk.

Benchmark command:

```shell
fio --name=sync_rand_64k_{read, write}s  --rw=rand{read, write}  --direct=1 --ioengine=sync --bs=64k --numjobs=4 --iodepth=128 --size=1G --group_reporting --directory=/tmp/
```

title: Allow fall back to account ID for AWS
body:
<!-- Describe the changes in this PR -->

Fixes #1807

We now allow the identity check fallback to AccountId if UserId does not match, because:
1.. In the case where multiple IAM users belong to a single root account, those users normally share the visibility of the VMs, so we do not need to identify them with each other. (There can be some cases, when an IAM user is given a limited permission by the admin, we may ignore that case for now, or print out a warning if the underlying userid changed for a cluster).
2. In the case where multiple users belong to an organization, those users will have different account id, so fallback works.

title: [AWS] Use Account ID instead of user id for identity check
body:
(we can make account id as the fallback option, which means we check the user id first and then check account id if the first one does not match and print warnings), reason
In the case where multiple IAM users belong a single root account, those users normally share the visibility of the VMs, so we do not need to identity them with each other, i.e. sky status -r will be executed correctly. (There can be some cases, when an IAM user is given a limited permission for the instances it can see by the admin, we may ignore that case for now, or print out a warning if the underlying userid changed for a cluster).
In the case where the multiple users belong to an organization, those users will have different account id, so the proposed method work

title: [multi-node] Make collocation possible for multiple clouds
body:
ML training may require high network bandwidth for multiple nodes in the cluster. Many clouds provide method to collocated the nodes.

We can provide an option:
```
resources:
  accelerators: A100:8
  collocate_group_name: my-collocation-group

num_nodes: 2
```

AWS: placement group
GCP: resources policy https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/instances/define-instance-placement#create
  1. Create policy for a region:
  ```
  gcloud compute resource-policies create group-placement POLICY_NAME \
      --availability-domain-count DOMAIN_COUNT \
      --region REGION \
      --project PROJECT_ID
  ```
  2. Fill in the yaml template with the policy address:
  ```
  gcloud compute resource-policies describe POLICY_NAME
  ```
  ```
   machineType: {{instance_type}}
        resourcePolicies: [https://www.googleapis.com/compute/v1/projects/project-xxx/regions/region_name/resourcePolicies/policy_name]
  ```

title: [Spot] Spot jobs only failover through the regions in ssh_proxy_command
body:
<!-- Describe the changes in this PR -->

To reproduce the problem:
1. Have a `~/.sky/config.yaml`:
```
aws:
  vpc_name: skypilot-test-vpc
  use_internal_ips: True
  ssh_proxy_command:
    us-east-2: ssh -W %h:%p -i ~/.ssh/sky-key -o StrictHostKeyChecking=no ec2-user@jump-ip
```
2. `sky spot launch --gpus A100:8 --cloud aws echo hi`

In the current the master, the failover of the spot cluster to be launched will go through all the regions, while the expected behavior should be similar as `sky launch --gpus A100:8 --cloud aws`, i.e. only trying the zones in the us-east-1 specified in `ssh_proxy_command`

This PR fixes the problem mentioned above.

Future TODOs:

title: Failed to install/run Redis with SkyPilot
body:
User's application requires installing Redis server to run the service. 
```
setup: |
  curl -fsSL https://packages.redis.io/gpg | sudo gpg --dearmor -o /usr/share/keyrings/redis-archive-keyring.gpg
  echo "deb [signed-by=/usr/share/keyrings/redis-archive-keyring.gpg] https://packages.redis.io/deb $(lsb_release -cs) main" | sudo tee /etc/apt/sources.list.d/redis.list
  sudo apt-get update
  sudo apt-get install redis -y
```
However, our Ray cluster currently occupies the port (6379) that Redis server used by default.
Consequencely, `sudo apt install redis` will throw below errors
```
...
See "systemctl status redis-server.service" and "journalctl -xe" for details.
invoke-rc.d: initscript redis-server, action "start" failed.
● redis-server.service - Advanced key-value store
     Loaded: loaded (/lib/systemd/system/redis-server.service; disabled; vendor preset: enabled)
     Active: activating (auto-restart) (Result: exit-code) since Thu 2023-03-16 21:14:23 UTC; 28ms ago
       Docs: http://redis.io/documentation,
             man:redis-server(1)
    Process: 53134 ExecStart=/usr/bin/redis-server /etc/redis/redis.conf (code=exited, status=1/FAILURE)
   Main PID: 53134 (code=exited, status=1/FAILURE)
     Status: "Redis is loading..."
dpkg: error processing package redis-server (--configure):
 installed redis-server package post-installation script subprocess returned error exit status 1
dpkg: dependency problems prevent configuration of redis:
 redis depends on redis-server (<< 6:7.0.9-1rl1~focal1.1~); however:
  Package redis-server is not configured yet.
 redis depends on redis-server (>= 6:7.0.9-1rl1~focal1); however:
  Package redis-server is not configured yet.
...
```
basically the redis server can not be correctly setup.

I had to first `ray stop` and then my `sudo apt install redis` work.
What's worse, after installation the ray and redis server can't not co-exist unless we specify different ports for them.
for example `ray start --port 6380`
We should probably change the port occupied by Ray to some non-popular ports...

body:
Partially fixes #1331 by making `sky gpunode` reuse existing cluster if possible.

Before:

```
$ sky gpunode --gpus V100
```

After
```
$ sky gpunode --gpus V100
$ sky gpunode --gpus V100 # reuses gpunode
```

Notes:
- I wanted to add a smoke test, but I couldn't because `sky gpunode` automatically ssh's into the cluster and there is no detach option.

body:
<!-- Describe the changes in this PR -->

According to the #1745, we now set the CANCELLED state after the spot cluster is fully clean up. That will keep the spot job in the previous job for a while, which can feels unresponsive.
Thanks to @suquark 's [great idea](https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/pull/1745#discussion_r1137558903), we are now adding a CANCELLING state for the spot job to improve the UX.

This will also solve the issue https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/pull/1745#issuecomment-1472176053
Because, previously, our spot job is not set to terminal state immediately, the log streaming will misclassified it as preempted.

title: [Spot] Kill the process on workers when head node preempted in multi-node spot clusters
body:
We currently rely on `sky cancel` to kill the user program on all the nodes when one node is preempted in the spot cluster. After cancelling the job, we will `sky launch` again with the same cluster name. In that case, we will reuse the previous alive nodes and try to recover the preempted one. This works fine when the worker node is preempted.
However, if the head node is preempted, the `sky cancel` will not take effect, and the worker nodes may still have the user program running (hanging). That will fail the user programs that require the GPUs to be run.

title: Fix bug for GCP auth config
body:
<!-- Describe the changes in this PR -->

Fixes https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/issues/1771.
What happened to the user was the config file `~/.config/gcloud/configurations/config_default` does not exist even if the user already successfully run
```
gcloud init
gcloud auth application-default login
```
which triggered the below error.
https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/blob/704a9dda70a9835ee9a0e1eea7543377dc0db443/sky/clouds/gcp.py#L564-L566

However, it's actually possible that `config_default` doesn't exist and may not be the config in use. Instead, what's specified in`~/.config/gcloud/active_config` is the one in use.
(we briefly discussed this in https://github.com/skypilot-org/skypilot/pull/1539)
So we shouldn't assume the existence of `config_default`.

In addition, our logic for backing up the config file seems unnecessary. I removed them and tested
- [x] `sky launch` and login to the VM. The GCP config is normal.
- [x] `sky launch` and login to the VM. `gsutil ls gs://[a-private-bucket]` works.
- [x] `sky spot launch "echo hi"` with a GCP controller works normally
- [ ] `sky launch` with `os-login` enabled with the account

Looks to me we don't really need to backup the `config_default`? I had a discussion with @Michaelvll and it seems that if the above things work without `config_default`, we may be safe to remove it.

title: Error on retrieving all regions for Azure
body:
When using the command:
```bash
python -m sky.clouds.service_catalog.data_fetchers.fetch_azure --all-regions
```

Currently the regions: centraluseuap and eastus2euap are retrieved in
```bash
az account list-locations  --query "[?not_null(metadata.latitude)] .{RegionName:name , RegionDisplayName:regionalDisplayName}" -o json
```
but do not have any data in https://prices.azure.com/api/retail/prices leading the assertion
```python
assert 'productName' in df.columns, (region, df.columns)
```
to fail and not saving any retrieved data, leaving ~/.sky/catalogs/v5/azure/vms.csv untouched.

As a workaround I have changed the az command to:
```bash
az account list-locations  --query "[?not_null(metadata.latitude) && \!(contains(name,'centraluseuap') || contains(name,'eastus2euap'))] .{RegionName:name , RegionDisplayName:regionalDisplayName}" -o json
```

But it would be nice to not lose already retrieved data in case of a failure in some regions.

title: Consider making `sky spot logs` automatically restart the controller
body:
From user, who was trying to run `sky spot logs --controller 2 >> my.log`:
> btw, I’m realizing that if i run sky spot logs --controller 2 while the spot controller is not UP then it just doesn’t print out anything (instead of re-starting the spot controller for me). This is inconvenient if instead of trying to see the logs I’m using this in a script, like trying to save the logs to a file, that will then silently not do anything. Would it make sense that any sky spot command automatically re-starts the spot controller if it’s not UP?

title: Revamp SSH config implementation to fix issues like duplicates, overwriting, orphans
body:
We've seen duplicates, overwriting, orphans, and issues like that in `~/.ssh/config` (e.g., #1763). @Michaelvll and I discussed some potential fixes and enhancements to revamp our SSH config impl:

- [ ] Attempt to fix ssh config problem by always using `Include` even for single-node clusters
  - may have some back compat issues to worry about

title: Make `show-gpus` show `DEVICE_MEMORY`
body: When playing with an example where I was figuring out what types of GPUs would fit my model, I wanted to quickly look up a GPU's device memory. Currently `show-gpus` shows `HOST_MEMORY`, and it'd be great to show `DEVICE_MEMORY` as well. It should be about surfacing this info from the catalog CSVs.

title: .ssh/config overwriting bug
body:
SkyPilot occasionally adds duplicate entries into my .ssh/config for the same cluster, which creates issues when I down the cluster or create a new one with the same name (but new IP). I found the bug, where it's not scanning for existing clusters in the config file all the way to the start of the file, only the second line. This fixes that.

Not sure which tests to run here? Running the full suite seems like overkill?

- [ ] Backward compatibility tests: `bash tests/backward_comaptibility_tests.sh`

title: Support barrier for in the run section
body:
A request from our user:
> Can sky provide some lightweight alternative to `mpirun` that achieves the equivalent of “running certain command on all nodes of a cluster initiated from head node, and block until this finishes on all nodes before proceeding with the next bash command”?
Right now I think there is only a barrier between setup and run, but further coordination within run is not supported by sky. I’m hoping that we can get rid of the openmpi dependency, and one of the current usage pattern is in the sky run section do something like
```
if [ "${SKY_NODE_RANK}" == "0" ]; then
  for _ in `seq max_attempt`; do
    mpirun ... kill_dangling_processes_on_all_machines
    mpirun ... build_target_on_all_machines
    mpirun ... run_target_on_all_machines
  done
fi
```

<s>
A possible solution:

```
run: |
  for _ in `seq max_attempt`; do
    # kill_dangling_processes_on_all_machines
    sky_barrier
    # build_target_on_all_machines
    sky_barrier
    # run_target_on_all_machines
    sky_barrier
  done
```

The `sky_barrier` should be a bash function with the following behavior:
1. Create an indicator file `/tmp/{task_id}-node-{SKYPILOT_NODE_RANK}-stage-{s}` on the first node (head node of the task) in the `SKYPILOT_NODE_IPS`, where `s` is the counter within the current task.
2. Keep checking if there are `echo "$SKYPILOT_NODE_IPS" | wc -l` indicator files on the head node of the task, before we continue the execution.
</s>



The user further requested that the returncode is needed for the commands:
> to further clarify - ideally there can be a command somewhat like mpirun , where you call it from the head node like:
`mpirun some_command arg1 arg2 …` and the effect is that it will run `some_command arg1 arg2 …` on all the machines and wait until it finishes on all machines, and return code 0 only if all of them exited with code 0
I think just providing a sky_barrier won’t be enough since there still needs to be some way to initiate the commands from the head node - where the decision logic of what further commands to execute depends on the return code of previous commands.

A possible solution (confirmed by the user):
```
run: |
  if [ "${SKY_NODE_RANK}" == "0" ]; then
    for i in `seq max_retry`; do
      sky run_on_nodes command arg1 arg2 # exitcode 0 if succeeded; otherwise, nonzero.
      sky run_on_nodes command arg1 arg2
    done
  fi
```

implementation details:
1. We add the `run_on_nodes` in our clis but not expose it to the `sky --help`
2. For the `run_on_nodes`:
  a. check the environment variable `$SKYPILOT_NODE_RANK` to make sure it is only executed on the head node.
  b. execute the command on all of `SKYPILOT_NODE_IPS` with ssh.
  c. aggregate the exit codes from all the nodes.

title: “sky down --purge” does not work after I switch GCP users
body: ## How to reproduce 1. Login with user A and manually shut down a cluster ``` gcloud init gcloud auth application-default login sky launch -c mycluster hello_sky.yaml ssh mycluster - sudo shutdown -h now ``` 2. Login with user B and try to delete `mycluster` ``` gcloud init gcloud auth application-default login sky down -p mycluster # This does not work ```

title: Catalog missing instances in some GCP region
body:
Our catalog currently doesn't have a complete list of instance types supported in region `us-central2-b`.
It may cause problems for TRC users who could have access to that region.

Also, we should try to fetch tpu pricing automatically with the coming new fetcher.

title: [TPU] Disable TPU node for TPU v4
body:
TPU-v4 arch doesn't support TPU node ([ref](https://cloud.google.com/tpu/docs/v4-users-guide))
```
For Cloud TPU v4, only the TPU VM architecture is supported, so all TPUs referenced in this document use the TPU VM architecture.
```
We should disable it during resource checking.

title: Set TPU VM the default option
body:
<!-- Describe the changes in this PR -->

This PR changes the default for TPU from TPU node to TPU VM as the former is now being deprecated by GCP.
for example, the tpu-v4 arch doesn't support TPU node ([ref](https://cloud.google.com/tpu/docs/v4-users-guide))
```
For Cloud TPU v4, only the TPU VM architecture is supported, so all TPUs referenced in this document use the TPU VM architecture.
```

<!-- Describe the tests ran -->
<!-- Unit tests (tests/test_*.py) are part of GitHub CI; below are tests that launch on the cloud. -->

Tested (run the relevant ones):

- [ ] Disable tpu node for v4

title: GCP identity/UX: ClusterOwnerIdentityMismatchError should hint how-to-fix
body:
We've seen
```
sky.exceptions.ClusterOwnerIdentityMismatchError: 'xxx' (GCP) is owned by account 'xxx@berkeley.edu\n [project_id=abc-123]', but the activated account is 'xxx@berkeley.edu\n [project_id=abc-456]'.
```
 It can be quite confusing for an initial user.

We should hint on how to fix. E.g., "To fix, switch to the correct GCP account/configuration using `gcloud ...`".

title: GCP permissions: make `sky check` check permissions and fail early
body:
We've heard recurring reports that several permission errors showed up during `sky launch` -> `setup_gcp_authentication` ->
* `setCommonInstanceMetadata?alt=json returned "Required 'iam.serviceAccounts.actAs' permission for <project>`
* `Required 'compute.projects.get' permission for <project>`
* ...add more...

We should make `sky check` check a growing list of minimum permissions and fail early.

title: Add a pytorch elastic example
body: This PR adds an example for [PyTorch elastic](https://pytorch.org/docs/stable/distributed.elastic.html), which is the fault-tolerant/elastic version of `torch.distributed`. Tested (run the relevant ones): - [x] `sky launch resnet-elastic.yaml` and manually killed the worker node. the training successfully recovered. - [ ] keep or remove `spot/resnet.yaml`?

title: `sky queue` shows unnecessary error for auto-down cluster
